coal.label: % change since Jan. 2000
coal.description:
One of Trump’s signature campaign promises was to bring back lost coal mining jobs. Though it’s not a macroeconomic indicator like the other numbers we’ve chosen, Trump’s success in doing helping down-and-out coal miners could be critical to maintaining his populist appeal.

Unfortunately, the coal industry is in structural decline, due to low prices for oil and gas and a boom in renewables. If Trump props up the coal industry with subsidies he might be able to deliver on his promise, but doing so could cost jobs elsewhere. (TK: Link to Chris and Cassie’s story)

unemployment.label: % unemployed
unemployment.description: One of the signature accomplishments of Obama’s eight years in office has been the steady rebound in the unemployment rate. In November the unemployment fell to 4.6%, down from a high of 10% in 2009. Trump inherits a stronger position than either of his recent predecessors, which might be why on the campaign trail he repeatedly said the unemployment rate was actually 42%.

poverty.label: % below poverty line
poverty.description: Inequality was a signature theme of both Clinton and Trump’s campaigns. Both promised, albeit in very different language, to bring prosperity back to Americans that feel shut out. The poverty rate is only one measure of America’s huddling masses, but it clearly shows their declining fortunes in the wake of the 2008 recession. Though the rate improved in 2015 it remains far from its stable, Bush-era level of 12.5%. For Trump that task made be harder by Republicans who are eager to to rollback the social safety net.

gdp.label: % change
gdp.description: If there is one number that economists use to sum up the health of the US economy, it's growth in the gross domestic product. Both Bush and Obama entered office during recessions and over both their presidencies GDP growth averaged about 2.5%. Trump comes into office in a stronger position, but may have set himself unattainable goals. Like other politicians before him, Trump has pledged to take the US to 4% growth and beyond—a rate rarely seen outside wartime. The last time growth exceeded 4% was in the year 2000, just before the economy slid into recession.

labor.label: % active in labor force
labor.description:
However, Trump is right that there is something fishy about the unemployment rate. Labor force participation—the percent of people at work or actively looking for work—has fallen 3.5 percentage points during Obama’s presidency. Lower participation means fewer people count towards the unemployment rate.

Consequently, the “worst labor force participation rate in 40 years” has become a popular talking point for critics on the right, including Trump, though demographic forces, rather than political ones, are largely to blame. Trump may well find it impossible to improve labor participation—unless he plans on putting retiring baby boomers back to work.
